comments.raw_text: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 An image file called ad.gif is not always displayed. For example in the Google image search result page for ad.gif, click on any image labeled ad.gif, and then on the back button. The image has been replaced by white space! When testing locally I find that when an HTML refers to an image called ad.gif (or ad.png) in the SAME directory (), the image appears okay. If it is ANOTHER directory (), it is replaced by white space. Thinking it might be connected with the ad blocker, I tested this with a clean profile. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. http://images.google.com/images?q=ad.gif&hl=en&btnG=Search+Images 2. click on any image called "ad.gif" (or "AD.gif") 3. click on the back button Actual Results: ad.gif displays as white space Expected Results: displayed the image
comments.text: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 An image file called ad.gif is not always displayed. For example in the Google image search result page for ad.gif, click on any image labeled ad.gif, and then on the back button. The image has been replaced by white space! When testing locally I find that when an HTML refers to an image called ad.gif (or ad.png) in the SAME directory (), the image appears okay. If it is ANOTHER directory (), it is replaced by white space. Thinking it might be connected with the ad blocker, I tested this with a clean profile. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. http://images.google.com/images?q=ad.gif&hl=en&btnG=Search+Images 2. click on any image called "ad.gif" (or "AD.gif") 3. click on the back button Actual Results: ad.gif displays as white space Expected Results: displayed the image

WFM, Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060519 Minefield/3.0a1 ID:2006051905 [cairo]

Are you sure you don't have any ad blockers (extension, other softwares like firewall etc)?

comments.text:
(In reply to comment #1)
> WFM, Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060519
> Minefield/3.0a1 ID:2006051905 [cairo]
> 
> Are you sure you don't have any ad blockers (extension, other softwares like
> firewall etc)?
> 
Yes - I used a profile with no ad blockers. The firewall I use is ZoneAlarm. IE displays the page perfectly, so I can't see how this could be caused by the firewall. What is strange is that the image appears the first time and only disppears when you return to the Google page.

See also the difference between a reference to an IMG file in the same directory and in a different directory.

What happens when you browse the Google image page?

comments.text:
(In reply to comment #3)
> (In reply to comment #2)

> > What happens when you browse the Google image page?
> Nothing special. Images are displayed. Perhaps you could upload somewhere a
> testcase that reproduce the problem.

The Google images search page is the test case. I could upload something else, but I don't think it would add anything helpful. If you definitely clicked on an "ad.gif" file and then returned to the Google image search page and the image was still there, then there must be something different somehow. 

It would be good if someone else found the same problem.

(In reply to comment #7)
> See also http://kb.mozillazine.org/Images_or_animations_don%27t_load
> 
Thanks very much for this tip. Image 4 (ads.gif) is not displayed. Now I feel I'm getting somewhere.

I still don't understand what is doing the ad blocking, and why only in Firefox, not IE. I'll check it out further and report back when I find the culprit.

Thanks again.

comments.text:
About 15 months ago I added a userContent.css file and completely forgot about it.
(see the link at http://www.mozilla.org/support/firefox/adblock.html)

After removing this css file everything works normally.

Thanks everybody for your help. It was slowly driving me crazy!
comments.raw_text:
